statement: The description of the spatiotemporal invariant risk minimization (ST-IRM) loss lacks detailed mathematical derivation and intuitive explanations, particularly regarding the specific implementation details of the masking function.
The novelty of the proposed methods needs to be proven, as the masking strategy appears similar to existing methods like Diffusion Convolution Neural Network.

The mathematical foundations of the masking function operation are unclear - what is the 'κ' operation and how does it change the orientation of the feature set of X_t, and what is the significance of the m operation beyond standardization.

The utilization of spatiotemporal features through spatiotemporal invariant risk minimization (ST-IRM) loss is unclear, particularly how the proposed network can utilize spatiotemporal features when EEG data is transformed to frequency domain.

The proposed method, including the model architecture and graph construction, is very similar to Corr-DCRNN, and the authors apply invariant feature learning without clarifying the necessity of this specific feature learning method.
An ablation study examining domain generalization methods is needed, as there are many available approaches and the effectiveness of each component should be evaluated.
The evaluation method for cross-domain invariance of the extracted features is not specified.
Tackling distribution shift issues and improving model generalization are important for clinical settings, and learning cross-domain invariant feature representations is a reasonable approach.
The motivation of addressing subject-independent classification challenges in the EEG domain is good and represents an important research direction.
An ablation study examining the impact of each loss function should be included, such as evaluating model performance after completely removing the IRM loss.
Using K-means clustering to group subjects for applying IRM does not seem reasonable, as each subject should be treated as a distinct domain since each has unique subject-specific features.

There is no specialized design tailored to seizure detection, and the proposed method appears more like a generalized approach for all EEG-based brain disease classification tasks under the subject-independent setup.

The baseline methods included in the comparison are insufficient, and a comparison with simpler models like TCN and vanilla Transformer should be presented, as many complex EEG classification methods fail to outperform these simpler approaches.
